Topological transitivity and wandering intervals for group actions on the line â„â„\mathbb{R}

Abstract

For every group GğºG, we show that either GğºG has a topologically transitive action on the line â„â„\mathbb{R} by orientation-preserving homeomorphisms, or every orientation-preserving action of GğºG on â„â„\mathbb{R} has a wandering interval. According to this result, all groups are divided into two types: transitive type and wandering type, and the types of several groups are determined. We also show that every finitely generated orderable group of wandering type is indicable. As a corollary, we show that if a higher rank lattice Î“Î“\Gamma is orderable, then Î“Î“\Gamma is of transitive type.

2 Background and main results

The dynamical system for group actions on one-manifolds has been intensively studied. One may consult [7, 11] for a systematic introduction to this area. Group actions on the real line â„â„\mathbb{R} are closely related to the study of orderability of a group. In fact, a countable group GğºG is orderable (that is, GğºG admits a left-invariant total order relation) if and only if it admits a faithful orientation-preserving action on the real line (see [12, Prop. 2.1]). Many important groups coming from geometry and topology are known to be orderable or nonorderable (see e.g. [3, 5, 17, 20]). In addition, an orderable group may possess some interesting algebraic properties (see e.g. [10, 13, 19]).

The purpose of the paper is to classify group actions on â„â„\mathbb{R} by means of topological transitivity. One may consult [16] for some related investigations. We first give the following dichotomy theorem.

Theorem 2.1.

Let GğºG be a group. Then either GğºG has a topologically transitive action on the line â„â„\mathbb{R} by orientation-preserving homeomorphisms, or every orientation-preserving action of GğºG on â„â„\mathbb{R} has a wandering interval.

We should note that the â€œdichotomy phenomenonâ€ in Theorem 2.1 is far from being true for group actions on spaces of dimension â‰¥2absent2\geq 2. For example, if Dğ·D is the closed unit disk in the plane and S2superscriptğ‘†2S^{2} is the unit sphere in â„3superscriptâ„3\mathbb{R}^{3}, then any one point union of Dğ·D and S2superscriptğ‘†2S^{2} admits no topologically transitive homeomorphism but admits a homeomorphism with no wandering open set.

Theorem 2.1 motivates us to give the following definition.

Definition 2.2.

A group GğºG is of transitive type if it has a topologically transitive action on the line â„â„\mathbb{R} by orientation-preserving homeomorphisms; it is of wandering type if every orientation-preserving action of GğºG on â„â„\mathbb{R} has a wandering interval.

Theorem 2.3.

The following groups are of transitive type: the nonabelian free group â„¤âˆ—â„¤â„¤â„¤\mathbb{Z}*\mathbb{Z}; any super-poly-infinite-cyclic group G=N0âŠ³N1âŠ³â€¦âŠ³Nk={e}ğºcontains-as-subgroupsubscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘’G=N_{0}\rhd N_{1}\rhd...\rhd N_{k}=\{e\} having the name (n0,n1,â€¦,nkâˆ’2)subscriptğ‘›0subscriptğ‘›1â€¦subscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜2(n_{0},n_{1},...,n_{k-2}) with some ni=1subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–1n_{i}=1; any poly-infinite-cyclic, non super-poly-infinite-cyclic group GğºG; the Baumslag-Solitar group Bâ€‹(1,n)ğµ1ğ‘›B(1,n) with nâ‰ 0ğ‘›0n\not=0 and nâ‰ âˆ’1ğ‘›1n\not=-1.

The following groups are of wandering type: finite groups; the infinite cyclic group â„¤â„¤\mathbb{Z}; Sâ€‹Lâ€‹(2,â„¤)ğ‘†ğ¿2â„¤SL(2,\mathbb{Z}); finite index subgroups of Sâ€‹Lâ€‹(n,â„¤)ğ‘†ğ¿ğ‘›â„¤SL(n,\mathbb{Z}) with nâ‰¥3ğ‘›3n\geq 3; any super-poly-infinite-cyclic group G=N0âŠ³N1âŠ³â€¦âŠ³Nk={e}ğºcontains-as-subgroupsubscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘’G=N_{0}\rhd N_{1}\rhd...\rhd N_{k}=\{e\} having the name (âˆ’1,âˆ’1,â€¦,âˆ’1)11â€¦1(-1,-1,...,-1); the Baumslag-Solitar group Bâ€‹(1,âˆ’1)ğµ11B(1,-1).

Recall that a group is indicable if it has a homomorphism onto the infinite cyclic group. One may consult [2, 8, 19] for the discussions about indicability of orderable groups.

Theorem 2.4.

If GğºG is a finitely generated nontrivial orderable group of wandering type, then GğºG is indicable.

A higher rank lattice is a lattice of a simple Lie group with finite center and with real rank â‰¥2absent2\geq 2. The 1-dimensional Zimmerâ€™s rigidity conjecture says that every continuous action of a higher rank lattice on the circle ğ•Š1superscriptğ•Š1\mathbb{S}^{1} must factor through a finite group action. Though the conjecture is still open now, Ghys (see [6]) and Burger-Monod (see [4]) proved independently the existence of periodic points for such actions. This implies that 1-dimensional Zimmerâ€™s rigidity conjecture is equivalent to that no higher rank lattice is orderable. We get immediately the following corollary by Theorem 2.4 and Theorem 6.5 in the appendix.

Corollary 2.5.

Suppose GğºG is a higher rank lattice. If GğºG is orderable, then it is of transitive type.

3 The dichotomy theorem

Lemma 3.1.

Let GğºG be a group. Suppose GğºG has no topologically transitive action on the line â„â„\mathbb{R} by orientation-preserving homeomorphisms. Then, for every action Ï•:Gâ†’Homeo+â€‹(â„):italic-Ï•â†’ğºsubscriptHomeoâ„\phi:G\rightarrow{\rm Homeo}_{+}(\mathbb{R}) and for every xâˆˆâ„ğ‘¥â„x\in\mathbb{R}, Gâ€‹xÂ¯Â¯ğºğ‘¥\overline{Gx} is countable; in particular, Gâ€‹xÂ¯Â¯ğºğ‘¥\overline{Gx} is nowhere dense.

Proof.

Assume to the contrary that there is some action Ï•0:Gâ†’Homeo+â€‹(â„):subscriptitalic-Ï•0â†’ğºsubscriptHomeoâ„\phi_{0}:G\rightarrow{\rm Homeo}_{+}(\mathbb{R}) and some x0âˆˆâ„subscriptğ‘¥0â„x_{0}\in\mathbb{R} such that Gâ€‹x0Â¯Â¯ğºsubscriptğ‘¥0\overline{Gx_{0}} is uncountable. Then, by collapsing the maximal open intervals of â„âˆ–Gâ€‹x0Â¯â„Â¯ğºsubscriptğ‘¥0\mathbb{R}\setminus\overline{Gx_{0}}, we get an induced topologically transitive action of GğºG on either [0,1]01[0,1], or [0,1)01[0,1), or (0,1]01(0,1], or (0,1)01(0,1). By removing the endpoints of the phase space of the induced action if necessary, we get a topologically transitive action of GğºG on â„â„\mathbb{R} by orientation-preserving homeomorphisms. This contradicts the assumption.

5 Indicability

To prove Theorem 2.4, we need several well-known results about group actions on â„â„\mathbb{R}. The following lemma can be shown by the dynamical realization method (see [11, Theorem 2.2.19] and its remark).

Lemma 5.1.

Every countable nontrivial orderable group has a faithful orientation-preserving action on the line â„â„\mathbb{R} without fixed points.

The following lemma is the combination of [11, Proposition 2.1.12] and the remarks after it (see also [9]).

6 Appendix

In this section, we first supply some basic results about poly-cyclic groups, which have been used in the precious sections. One may consult [14] for more details.

Proposition 6.1.

Let GğºG be a poly-cyclic group and let Hğ»H be a subgroup of GğºG. Then Hğ»H is poly-cyclic.

Proposition 6.2 ([13]).

Let GğºG be a poly-cyclic group. Then GğºG is poly-infinite-cyclic if and only if GğºG is orderable.

Since every subgroup of an orderable group is orderable, we immediately get the the following corollary by Proposition 6.1 and Proposition 6.2.

Corollary 6.3.

Let GğºG be a poly-infinite-cyclic group. Then every non-trivial subgroup of GğºG is poly-infinite-cyclic.

Suppose GğºG is a poly-cyclic group. Then G=N0âŠ³N1âŠ³â€¦âŠ³Nk={e}ğºcontains-as-subgroupsubscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘’G=N_{0}\rhd N_{1}\rhd...\rhd N_{k}=\{e\} with Ni/Ni+1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–1N_{i}/N_{i+1} cyclic for each iğ‘–i. The following theorem is due to Margulis and Kazhdan (see e.g. [21, Theorem 8.1.2]).

Theorem 6.5.

Let Î“Î“\Gamma be a higher rank lattice and let Hğ»H be a normal subgroup of Î“Î“\Gamma. Then either Hğ»H is finite or Î“/HÎ“ğ»\Gamma/H is finite.
